prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in engineering would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in engineering would. Find the $3 \times 3$ matrix $\mathbf{M}$ such that
\[\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} y \\ z \\ x + y + z \end{pmatrix}\]for all real numbers $x,$ $y,$ and $z.$
gpt_response:
To find the matrix $\mathbf{M},$ we will evaluate $\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ term by term.

The first entry is $y,$ so the first row of $\mathbf{M}$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.$

The second entry is $z,$ so the second row of $\mathbf{M}$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$

The third entry is $x + y + z,$ so the third row of $\mathbf{M}$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$

Therefore,
\[\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][Note: A PhD in engineering (or mathematics) would be able to easily deduce the matrix by observing the pattern and evaluating by hand, rather than relying on any computational methods.]
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}?: To find the matrix $\mathbf{M},$ we will evaluate $\mathbf{M} \begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix}$ term by term.

The first entry is $y,$ so the first row of $\mathbf{M}$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.$

The second entry is $z,$ so the second row of $\mathbf{M}$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$

The third entry is $x + y + z,$ so the third row of $\mathbf{M}$ is $\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$

Therefore,
\[\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\][Note: A PhD in engineering (or mathematics) would be able to easily deduce the matrix by observing the pattern and evaluating by hand, rather than relying on any computational methods.]
